author: ElderScrolls
body:
I hate Apple products but the stock is solid. And it's for the same reason that I hate their products: they have a strong closed ecosystem.  I've had friends switch from Apple to PC/Android and it's a painful experience.

People will naturally continue to upgrade and buy in that system, including new products that sync into it.

I'm not sure if it'll be explosive growth. But it's not going anywhere.

Nonetheless, I'd rather put money in msft.

author: dolpherx
body:
tech is actually not one basket. The term "tech" is very misleading as we are at just the beginning of a way of doing business using "tech". Each tech company actually operates in a different industry for example, Apple is in consumer products, Amazon is in retail and cloud computing, Facebook is in Social Media and Advertising, Google is in Advertising, Netflix is in Content Media and Media Distribution, Microsoft is in work productivity software and cloud computing, Nvidia is in semiconductors, Uber in transportation, and the list goes on.

Eventually there will be new categories and there will be a reshuffle of the companies into the new categories. This has already started a couple of years ago and will continue to do so until basically all of the old companies that used to be in those categories are forgotten like old railroad companies and the new categories will be based of the new technology. Currently everything is grouped up in tech. If you think tech is just one basket then you will miss the boat as you will be trying to diversify too much and invest in old companies which the tech companies are about to turn obsolete. Sure some old companies will survive, but history has shown that companies come and go like empires.

author: HODL_monk
body: The most important thing is to learn about costs, emotional biases, and index funds. You will almost certainly lose money relative to an index fund, unless you put a lot of time into stock selection. You have to trade right twice, and pay taxes, to do individual stocks, versus fire and forget with index funds, and while I think those stocks are great, I have personally mistimed the in and out moves on stocks, including Microsoft (moved into it in 1999, LOL, and then dumped it in the following sell off, only to see it come back like crazy, once I was out of it...), so don't be so sure you can beat the market, because studies show most people can't, even with good stocks.

author: Jetboy3D
body:
I have a different opinion than most. The current price to earnings ratio is very high historically. So statistically it is riskier to invest right now than normal. Here's a link to a historical chart of stock market price versus PE.  [https://www.longtermtrends.net/price-earnings-ratio/](https://www.longtermtrends.net/price-earnings-ratio/) 

If you have inherited a large amount or have saved a large amount then I would recommend "cost averaging" into the market. Perhaps 3 to 7% a month.  If you have a relatively small amount that you are going to keep adding to each month then now is probably OK but perhaps we put a 1/3 in for 3 months.

Here's my Fund recommendation

VOO 77%

BND 10%

IAU 5% (physical gold ETF)

FXI 5% (China ETF)

FIVG 2% (Companies involved in 5G roll-out ETF)

Individual stock picks 1% - use a very small amount for learning. Look for long term plays when technology or society changes. Basically you are looking for a Microsoft or Amazon type of company. You will need to actively trade but realize that it takes a long time to learn how to do it well, so don't put much into it, or it's gambling.

Well, this is what I would tell my younger self.

Good luck.

author: TheSavingsGuy
body:
You can look for the smaller companies that become the future Amazon or Microsoft, but good luck with that and also being patient enough to hold on.

Let's say you decided to buy Microsoft on Jan. 2, 1998. You would have paid $16.39 per share. Around Christmas 1999, it's up to $58.75. You've more than tripled your money in less than two years. Do you hold or sell?

If you decide to sell, you miss the dot-com crash. If you don't, the stock is back around $21 at the end of 2000. Now, do you panic or stay in the game? 

9/11 happens, there's a recession in the U.S., Enron and WorldCom collapse, the war in Iraq begins, etc. Then gloom turns to boom. The market bounces back and Microsoft is around $36 in December 2007.

Then there's this whole global financial crisis near the end of the decade. Everybody panics. There's talk of a second Great Depression. In February 2009, the stock price is lower than where it was at the start of 1998. While you received some dividends over the years (Microsoft began paying a dividend in 2003), you're probably only looking at the price return and not the total return so you think you're down. You're probably thinking this is the worst investment ever (although it's not so bad when you think about Enron, WorldCom, Nortel, Pets.com, etc.).

It's not until near the end of 2016 that Microsoft is back to where it was during the dot-com frenzy. And then it triples over the next three or so years to $158.62 today. Would you have held on for 22 years or would you have sold somewhere in between? 

It's psychological and it's hard not to let your emotions take over when investing.

author: 4d39faaf-80c4-43b5
body:
The article does mention AMZN, as a 'big 5' of tech - pointing out that Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon, and Facebook are nearly 18% of the value of the SP500 right now.

However, the top 3, AAPL, MSFT, and GOOGL are somewhat unique, in that they all now have >1T$ market caps,  and somewhat grounded P/E ratios ( you have to admit AMZN's is a little wacky).

The other very notable thing about the big three is the BUYBACKS - we've recently seen TENS OF BILLIONS of dollars in buybacks from GOOGL, MSFT, AND APPL - these aren't debt-financed buybacks, but rather these companies cashflows are so insane they're paying dividends AND buying back billions of dollars in shares; AMZN is doing neither.

I'm not hating on AMZN by any means, I owns some shares, but I think this article argues, and I agree, that APPL, MSFT, GOOGL are in a 'tech blue chip' class which is all their own.

author: black_and_shredded
body:
If you think someone like Bernie or Warren being president will crash the stock market, I think you’re being crazy. Sure the deficit will
increase, but imagine a world where 10s of millions of people now have 10s of thousands of more dollars. A world where people dedicating a quarter of their income paying off medical debt doesn’t exist. Where the fuck do you think people will do with that extra money? 

**Spend it**. Spend it on food (WMT), clothes (LULU), computers/electronics (AAPL, MSFT), and stuff in general (AMZN). Most importantly, they will have disposable income necessary to even consider knowing wtf a “stock market” is and invest in stocks, 

If any of them get elected, I’m waiting for the inevitable 2-3 week pullback from fear of socialists destroying our economy but after that, I’m getting into long-term leaps and enjoying the ride.

author: Anglo14
body:
If they do their AR glasses right it could be a killer app with an impact on par with the iPhone. They'll probably release a minimal viable product sometime in the early 2020s when 5G becomes widespread then iterate it up to something more polished. The AR/VR product category is very compelling and will likely replace the laptop/tablet/smartphone as the main computing interface by the late 2020's/early 2030's.

Apple needs to speed up its product upgrade cycle- its design team has been a major bottleneck, for example taking years to upgrade the Mac Pro. Thats no way to win over the gaming market which is used to yearly GPU/CPU etc upgrades from the PC world. Hopefully Jony Ive's departure will allow more consistent and frequent product upgrades.

One the other players- Google is stagnant with a lazy and disjointed culture and management but has a lot of potential if it streamlines and regains its focus. Facebook has been hemorrhaging user trust but they own the social networking ecosphere. Microsoft under Nadella on the other hand has been a superstar with blistering product innovation and development and incredible leadership. Expect them to continue to win in the near future.

Tesla has the potential to be in the top 5. They've already overcome immense hurdles in achieving scale with their manufacturing and are lightyears ahead of the competition with autonomous driving, electric capabilities, and a software-centric Silicon Valley-style corporate structure. Their rapid obliteration of the German luxury auto industry shows how consumer preference strongly favors their vehicles- who wanted a Blackberry when the iPhone was released, even if the Blackberry's specs were more impressive on paper? Musk will likely continue to expand into other product categories such as utilities and other forms of transportation.

I think a game engine company like Unity or Epic Games has the potential to be in the top 5 with the rise of AR/VR and the expansion of the game platform beyond video games into a variety of immersive digital experiences. The Unity, Unreal, and Valve app and game stores are a portent of things to come.

author: WhyDoYouBlock
body:
OK, so this depends on what your goal is.

For long-term investments I would invest in MSFT, AAPL, maybe NFLX and SPY. You could gamble a couple hundred on options, but you would need time to watch them so that you don't get burned badly.

For short-term, you could look into CGC (I know LOLWEED, but they're stable financially), and AMD (could drop again like the two other times so be careful)

You could also play earnings, meaning buying stock before they announce earnings and see if the stock jumps up. Here's a [calendar](https://imgur.com/a/P9Ou2MR) for this months earnings report. Lots of big names this month so there are a few plays you could make, like AMD and INTC (Intel), or go with a bank like C, JPM, GS, BAC, PNC and more

author: PapaCharlie9

The solution is to not buy multiple ETFs that have the same exposure for asset class, size, style and region.

Btw, you probably have as much overlap in MSFT as you do with AAPL. They usually show up together.

author: noahsnumber1
body:
Depends. If you are looking for fun, you should probably just buy puts / calls on whatever you want since that’s just gambling with a a little bit of DD sprinkled in.
If you want to try to make money (very few autism’s here), you should probably look into selling options / selling credit spreads. It definitely can still be gambling (especially on a stock like ACB), but I’ve seen many strategies that seem to be able to make consistent returns if you are patient. A lot of people hate on it because it can be quite hard to make enough every trade to justify the potential losses (see: picking up pennies), but in my opinion doing something like selling credit spreads 1-2 months or more out will give a much easier exit in case things go wrong. 
In this market I’ve been having a really easy time selling put credit spreads on apple, Microsoft, sometimes amazon. I go pretty far otm, and those gains make up for my losses when I just buy options. Anyways, most people here don’t care about consistency or long term gains, but I definitely recommend something like put credit spreads, because even a 4-12% return every 2 weeks really compounds over time. It still takes tuning and DD tho, so be careful.

author: bfreis
body:
That option is almost entirely equivalent to a stock position: it's pretty deep ITM, with a delta greater than 0.9, about 3 weeks to expiration with a very small amount of extrinsic value so it won't be affected much by either time of IV crush.

I think the question becomes: would you be willing to hold a long position in MSFT into earnings? If yes, you could hold it. Otherwise, sell it.

If you want to bet on an explosive move beyond what the market has priced in, you could close that position, and then open one with much more gamma — maybe closer to expiration, maybe closer to ATM or slightly OTM. It becomes much more risky in the sense that it can very quickly become worthless. But on the other hand, there's more potential for huge gains.

So it's a trade off.

author: VCUBNFO
body:
>First off I believe German engineers are amongst the very best in the world 

Why do you think that?

> I believe most of those engineers would have the foresight to

Engineers are just a small part of it. Right now there are basic manufacturing jobs for everything from building engines, transmissions, oil filters, etc. Plus the jobs for assembling all that into cars. There are tons of things that have to be made and put together by workers now that simply aren't needed for EVs.

Also there are plenty of cases of companies full of really smart people failing to pivot to similar but different industries.  Look at how Google failed with Google+ or how Microsoft failed with mobile computers.

> That said what's stopping these large car companies from creating another company (whether it be a subsidiary or just a company they have majority voting shares in) and bypassing the unions?

The unions? If the union goes on strike, they can't build any sort of vehicles.

author: WhyDoYouBlock
body:
OK, so this depends on what your goal is.

For long-term investments I would invest in MSFT, AAPL, maybe NFLX and SPY. You could gamble a couple hundred on options, but you would need time to watch them so that you don't get burned badly.

For short-term, you could look into CGC (I know LOLWEED, but they're stable financially), and AMD (could drop again like the two other times so be careful)

You could also play earnings, meaning buying stock before they announce earnings and see if the stock jumps up. Here's a [calendar](https://imgur.com/a/P9Ou2MR) for this months earnings report. Lots of big names this month so there are a few plays you could make, like AMD and INTC (Intel), or go with a bank like C, JPM, GS, BAC, PNC and more

author: CardinalNumber
body: Everything that guy said was bullshit. PDT rules don't exist to be training wheels that try to help broke people trade without harming themselves. Day trade buying power regulations exist for the same reasons.

author: bulldozer1
body: Definitely put it into an IRA or 401k if applicable. Will give you substantial tax benefits. In terms of what you invest in, this sub is fairly useless, everybody just names the same 10-15 blue chip stocks over and over. There’s no “right” answer. If you don’t know what you’re doing in terms of investing I would suggest an ETF that tracks the market such as VOO. If you do know what you’re doing investing or want to learn how to pick individual stocks you’ll be better off using google to learn rather than waiting to hear this sub tell you MSFT, DIS, V, etc.

author: Glyndm
body:
I have been using Freetrade since around April last year with no real issues to date.  It doesn't have the selection you might get with the paid providers but you can access the majority of major UK and US stocks.  Trades are commission-free, providing you are willing to wait until 4pm UK time for the purchase to go through.  If you want immediate trades, it costs £1.  The app is basic and won't provide you with hugely in depth analysis, but it's easy enough to use and has met my needs adequately.

I am loath to give you any real advice as to how to invest your money as I only started last year and am certainly a novice investor.  My personal tact has been to mainly invest in companies that I considered 'safe bets' - Microsoft, Apple, Visa, Google - that were unlikely to tank anytime soon, although I did invest in Tesla too as I believe in the company, although it's a volatile stock.  If you want greater security, though, you could invest in index funds to ensure your investment is diversified - I imagine most people will recommend this route.

I would recommend doing some reading and research on your own, using sites such as Investopedia, and there are countless books on investing if you're interested.  Take what I've said with a large grain of salt, as I am no authority on the subject, but I just thought I'd try and help out a bit as I saw the only comment you'd had was snarky and unhelpful.

author: CCYCN
body: My 401k is fully invested in diversified equity mutual funds, as it always will be.  My Roth account is fully invested in stocks I like, stocks I think will be successful in the long term.  Google, Microsoft, Amazon, Tesla.  Trendy picks, but companies I think will continue to expand the next decade.  My personal account is mostly cash.  I dont think the market is going to crash, a 30 or 40% drop is pretty unrealitistic at this point.  But I do think we will see a pullback this year, as we see almost every year.  10% or so from the current highs is very likely.  When that happens, Ill take a look at individual stocks that may have dropped more than 10% and consider putting cash to work.  If it doesnt happen, my retirement accounts will benefit.  If it does happen, Ill feel better being able to take advantage.

author: ImakeVideo4Investing
body:
Before you start investing this and that, there's something else you need to learn that is more important than investing, and that's yourself. You need to learn to control your emotion. What I mean by that is when the stock price fall, you can't panic, fear, and just sell your shares. You can't let your emotion of fear dedicate your decision. Also, you need to be patience. If you are hasty you can miss out on important information that may impact your portfolio. You need to able to have faith in your investment even though they may be in negative. But most importantly you need to study and research your investment thoroughly. What's going around the world that can impact your investment (for better or worse)? What can happen in the world that can impact your investment (for better or worse)? If you have done your study and research, and you purchased your investment, then you should be confident in your investments even when the stock is not doing well.

Second: stock market will crash eventually. It will happen, over and over. But, they will always recover, and they will break new record every. Single. Time. Yes, not every single company is gonna make it, but majority of the companies will. This is why you need to understand what you're investing. For example when market crash happen, Microsoft will crash. Disney will crash. Apple will crash. Amazon will crash. But they will recover because of what these companies represent, and their foothold in the world. Like I said over and over, you have to study and research the company in your investment. That's why I personally believe studying and researching the investment is the most important job because you're trying to build strong portfolio that can withstand the crash, and thrive afterward to break new records. And don't be persuade by what the social media, news, or people around you are saying. They can't predict the future, but you can research and see what is going around the world that can impact your portfolio.

Third: time in the market will beat timing the market for most investors.

Fourth: if you don't feel comfortable investing with large amount of money, start with $100. Get your emotion use to the feeling of stock market going up and down. Also get experience in meanwhile. When you feel comfortable and confident, invest $200, $300, and so on until you feel completely good about investing in thousands of dollar.

Last, and this may sound contradicting, know when to cut your loss. This comes from knowing what the company is going through. For example, if the company is going down from lawsuit, or legal issue, or whatever it is that will bankrupt the company, it's best to cut your loss and move on. Again, this is why you want to study and research your investment. Check if they have a records of lawsuit that they seem to unable to grow. See if there's law that's gonna change the fundamental of the company. Etc, etc, etc.

If you're interested check out the playlist [\[here\]](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL_JpNx7DVzBom-ZfxnN9C4faSEvBqmRI9) that cover basic introduction to online brokerage (which you need, and you want to pick the one that may benefit you the most based on what they offer in investment/retirement accounts), basic introduction to investment/retirement accounts (there are different accounts that you may not be qualify), and basic introduction to stock, ETF, Mutual Fund, and Bond.

Good luck, and invest wisely.

author: ImakeVideo4Investing
body:
I usually respond same thing to everyone asking for tips and advice for investing. So this post may be the same post some user might have already read. Anyway.... 

Before you start investing this and that, there's something else you need to learn that is more important than investing, and that's yourself. You need to learn to control your emotion. What I mean by that is when the stock price fall, you can't panic, fear, and just sell your shares. You can't let your emotion of fear dedicate your decision. Also, you need to be patience. If you are hasty you can miss out on important information that may impact your portfolio. You need to able to have faith in your investment even though they may be in negative. But most importantly you need to study and research your investment thoroughly. What's going around the world that can impact your investment (for better or worse)? What can happen in the world that can impact your investment (for better or worse)? If you have done your study and research, and you purchased your investment, then you should be confident in your investments even when the stock is not doing well.

Second: stock market will crash eventually. It will happen, over and over. But, they will always recover, and they will break new record every. Single. Time. Yes, not every single company is gonna make it, but majority of the companies will. This is why you need to understand what you're investing. For example when market crash happen, Microsoft will crash. Disney will crash. Apple will crash. Amazon will crash. But they will recover because of what these companies represent, and their foothold in the world. Like I said over and over, you have to study and research the company in your investment. That's why I personally believe studying and researching the investment is the most important job because you're trying to build strong portfolio that can withstand the crash, and thrive afterward to break new records. When the market crash, think of it as “Black Friday sale”, and buy more investment if you can.

Third: don't be persuade by what the social media, news, or people around you are saying. They can't predict the future, but you can research and see what is going around the world that can impact your portfolio.

Fourth: time in the market will beat timing the market for most investors.

Fifth: if you don't feel comfortable investing with large amount of money, start with $100. Get your emotion use to the feeling of stock market going up and down. Also get experience in meanwhile. When you feel comfortable and confident, invest $200, $300, and so on until you feel completely good about investing in thousands of dollar.

Sixth: build yourself emergency fund too if you have a budget. Depend on your situation you might even want to build emergency fund before having to set money on the investment. The emergency fund purpose is to avoid touching your money in your investment/retirement account(s). Less money in your account mean less money you will make from interest. So you want to make sure you have emergency fund on the side to avoid touching your investment/retirement account. Popular belief is to have 3-6 months of expense fund build.

Last, and this may sound contradicting, know when to cut your loss. This comes from knowing what the company is going through. For example, if the company is going down from lawsuit, or legal issue, or whatever it is that will bankrupt the company, it's best to cut your loss and move on. Again, this is why you want to study and research your investment. Check if they have a records of lawsuit that they seem to unable to grow. See if there's law that's gonna change the fundamental of the company. Etc, etc, etc.

[https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL\_JpNx7DVzBom-ZfxnN9C4faSEvBqmRI9](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL_JpNx7DVzBom-ZfxnN9C4faSEvBqmRI9)

Link above is a playlist that cover basic introduction to online brokerage (which you need, and you want to pick the one that may benefit you the most based on what they offer in investment/retirement accounts), basic introduction to investment/retirement accounts (there are different accounts that you may not be qualify), and basic introduction to stock, ETF, Mutual Fund, and Bond.

Good luck, and invest wisely.
